body:
### Problem

`nvim_buf_get_offset`'s docs state that "a final EOL byte is counted if it would be written", so I would expect a `\n` byte to be written to disk when saving a new, unedited file, but it isn't.

### Steps to reproduce

`nvim --clean -u minimal.lua`

```lua
-- minimal.lua
local buf_len = function(bufnr)
  return vim.api.nvim_buf_get_offset(bufnr, vim.api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr))
end

local file_len = function(bufnr)
  return vim.fn.getfsize(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_name(bufnr))
end

local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(true, false)
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_name(bufnr, "empty.txt")
vim.api.nvim_buf_call(bufnr, function() vim.api.nvim_command("write") end)

assert(buf_len(bufnr) == 1, "buffer length is " .. buf_len(bufnr))
-- ðŸ’¥ is actually 0.
assert(file_len(bufnr) == 1, "file length is " .. file_len(bufnr))
```

### Expected behavior

If `eol` is on (which it is by default), the newline is written to disk.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.12.0-nightly+8e8f452

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

yes

### Operating system/version

macOS 15.5

### Terminal name/version

alacritty

### $TERM environment variable

alacrity

### Installation

nixpkgs

comment_data.body:
> I would expect a `\n` byte to be written to disk when saving a new, unedited file, but it isn't.

Then there would be no way to save an empty file.

It seems like the bug(s) are:

- `nvim_buf_line_count(0)` should return `0` for an empty file. Currently returns 1.
    - This may break things. And would conflict with `line('$')`.
- `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 1)` should return `0` for an empty file. Currently returns 1.

My understanding is that all buffers contain an implicit `\n` if `eol` (and `fixeol`) is enabled, so I think `nvim_buf_line_count` and `nvim_buf_get_offset`'s outputs are correct.


> Then there would be no way to save an empty file

`:set noeol | set nofixeol | write`

What you are requesting would cause a lot of cascading, surprising effects, for little gain.

> My understanding is that all buffers contain an implicit `\n` if `eol` (and `fixeol`) is enabled,

An empty file has zero lines, so 'eol' does not apply.

However, there is an uncomfortable historical Vim quirk, which is that `line('$') == 1` for an empty file. It's an old problem. The way that scripts detect an empty file is to check:

    empty(getline(1)) && 1 == line('$')

> An empty file has zero lines, so 'eol' does not apply

If `eol` only "activates" on non-empty buffers, does that mean that inserting `foo` in an empty buffer effectively inserts `foo\n` (and deleting `foo` deletes `foo\n`)? Not that there's anything wrong with that, I'm just thinking of the semantics.

> `line('$') == 1` for an empty file

Can we change both `line()` and `nvim_buf_line_count()`? If not, can we just change `nvim_buf_line_count()` or does it always have to be bug-for-bug equivalent with `line()`?

> does that mean that inserting `foo` in an empty buffer effectively inserts `foo\n`

Inserting anything introduces a line. And lines end with `\n`, by definition (though 'eol' and 'fixeol' allow the user to violate that definition).

> can we just change `nvim_buf_line_count()` or does it always have to be bug-for-bug equivalent with `line()`?

Doesn't have to match, but we also need to be mindful about avoiding confusion and surprises.

It may make sense to add an `opts` parameter to some of these functions to allow more control. That is backwards-compatible, and much more tractable.

> by definition

Either `eol` and `fixeol` exist or they don't. If they do, there's no definition or assumption one can make about a buffer's trailing newline other than "you have to check both settings to know if it has one".

> It may make sense to add an opts parameter

I agree that it makes sense for future compatibility, but I'm not sure how it would be used here.

For example, I would expect `vim.api.nvim_buf_get_offset(0, vim.api.nvim_buf_line_count(0))` to always return the exact number of bytes the file would have if the corresponding buffer was saved, without having to set any specific `opts`.

I think we should consider changing `nvim_buf_line_count` to return 0 for empty buffers  consistently (instead of only for "unloaded" buffers..). Should be a small change that's easy to revert if we get lots of complaints.
If we do, `nvim_buf_get_offset` should also be changed to return an error if given a line index of 1 on an empty buffer.
If we do, nvim_buf_get_lines should also be changed to return empty table for empty buffers. That will prevent issues like https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29904.

It seems like a `\n` is written to disk if the buffer has been edited, even if it's empty. If `nvim_buf_line_count(0)` is changed to return 0 on an empty buffer, should we also change `write`'s implementation to write 0 bytes, even if `eol` is turned on?

Also: 

> nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 1) should return 0 for an empty file. Currently returns 1 (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272#issuecomment-2930169402)

> I suggest improving "correctness", so more cases to return -1 (or whatever signals an empty buffer) when the buffer is indeed empty (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34216#issuecomment-2964695955)

@justinmk which semantics do we want?

> It seems like a `\n` is written to disk if the buffer has been edited, even if it's empty.

Then it's not empty, in that case. And we definitely don't want these functions disagreeing with `:write`, they must all be consistent amongst each other.

Need to find the exact steps to reproduce using `nvim --clean`. 

## Idea

Rather than patching `nvim_buf_line_count`/`byte2line`, I am starting to think [this might be a quirk with undo](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34199#issuecomment-2955987169). Maybe we just need to fix undo so that it doesn't leave a dangling newline. Or maybe we just need a documentation update that says "once you edit a buffer, it can never be made fully empty unless you set 'noeol'/'nofixeol'/whatever...")

Making a buffer's contents depend on its editing history seems like an absolute tragedy.

If I start with an unedited, empty buffer where `nvim_buf_line_count(0)` is 0 and `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 0)` is 0 (or -1, still not sure what we want), then `nvim_input("ia<BS>")` oughta bring me back to the initial state.

> Making a buffer's contents depend on its editing history seems like an absolute tragedy.

That is why [my suggestion](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272#issuecomment-2972860483) is to fix that... ("fix undo" instead of tweaking the results of nvim_buf_line_count et al).

> If I start with an unedited, empty buffer where `nvim_buf_line_count(0)` is 0 and `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 0)` is 0 (or -1, still not sure what we want), then `nvim_input("ia<BS>")` oughta bring me back to the initial state.

That was literally [my suggestion](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272#issuecomment-2972860483).

I don't know what kind of dragons it might awake though.

Retitled and will consider this the tracking issue for #34199 where a lot of duplicate discussion happened.

# Status

## Analysis

See [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272#issuecomment-2972860483) , it seems like undo/`<bs>`/`dd`/etc does not return a buffer to "empty" state after edits are made.

## Test case / repro

From https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34199#issuecomment-2955987169 : 

> > Again, whether memline is uninitialized is not an internal state. It's a state that has a meaning to plugins.
> 
> If I add text to an empty buffer, then undo them with `u` so that the buffer is empty again, byte2line/line2byte return 1 instead of -1. They should always return -1 for an empty buffer.
> 
> Repro:
> 
> ```lua
> vim.cmd[[edit test.txt]]
> assert(-1 == vim.fn.line2byte(1))
> assert(-1 == vim.fn.byte2line(1))
> vim.api.nvim_input('ifoo<esc>u')
> -- Fails: returns [1, 1]
> vim.schedule(function()
>   assert(-1 == vim.fn.line2byte(1))
>   assert(-1 == vim.fn.byte2line(1))
> end)
> ```

> AFAICT nothing here is specific to `u`ndoing edits, as all the before-vs-after-like bugs can be reproduced by simply inserting and deleting text with `<BS>`.

Ok so it's not specific to undo. Providing precise repro steps, helps avoid back-and-forth.

Anyway, no, the task is not to fix the 6 individual features you listed. The task is to let buffers return to an actually-empty state, via `u` and `<bs>` and `dd`. The result of `byte2line` et al., is likely all driven by the same internal state. Allowing buffers to again reach that internal actually-empty state will implicitly fix `byte2line` et al.

The task is not to individually tweak every function like `byte2line`.

During this work, it may be discovered that changing this has too much "blast radius". We'll need to consider that. But at least then we can clarify the documentation.

> The task is to let buffers return to an actually-empty state

The behavior of the first 3 items I listed does not depend on the editing history, so there's nothing to "return to".
Oh right. As [mentioned](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272#issuecomment-2930934092) changing `nvim_buf_line_count` to return 0 for empty buffers is a low-risk first step.
